author: arnetheduck
content: I think the point I'm trying to make is different - with this feature, we're _drifing away_ from the home staker being an essential part of the network and instead encoding an explicit expression that _institutional stakes_ carry the network, and if the others want, well, sure, they can join in.

author: arnetheduck
content: "let's ask the institutional stakers if they'll play ball" is an expression of that ... shift

author: arnetheduck
content: that's how supernode designs work, in practical reality - only the supernodes are "peers" - so the way to follow up on this would ideally be to investigate what happens if we _remove_ them entirely, ie to what degree does the system work without them (a little bit like when we gave up block building to mev, a "circuit breaker" was added that when the external builders fail for N blocks, we'll try to heal the network with local block building hoping it has not atrophied

author: skylenet
content: After that, please also redeploy it on

author: arnetheduck
content: from the list here, as the eth_getBlobs RPC call optimisation shows, one way to get rid of the "help distribute" argument is indeed to have blobs "pre-distrubuted" so they can take longer to reach peers .. in the evm the equivalent is that gas is cheaper for hot storage - if we can find a mechanism to encode this in the blob price, that could be one way out ("low-latency premium")

author: dmitriishmatko
content:
I've found it https://www.migalabs.io/blog/post/observing-deterministic-subnets-in-the-wild
so here are attestations subnet subscription stats including non-validator nodes of course
https://migalabs.io/uploads/1_0619c85746.png

author: dmitriishmatko
content: I expect that those with 64 will be supernodes

author: dmitriishmatko
content: so it's 1000 out of 13000

author: jgm
content: nodes with 64 attestation subnets are likely running with a specific flag to make them do so, it doesn't provide any information about the number of validators they are running.

author: arnetheduck
content:
this is slightly different - previously, there was a validator-count-vs-subnet-count expectation (more validators = more subnets) - it was deemed unsustainable (and unenforceable) so the rule changed to be 2 subnets per beacon node - the migalabs crawler is also known to have some counting issues, so I would take the numbers with a bit of salt..

like jgm points out, these nodes might not running validators at all (in fact, they're kind of likely not to be because it puts strain on the node which is counterproductive for actual validation) and nothing says they'll extend the service to blobs (sometimes, it's useful to run such nodes to gather profit statistics for example)

author: arnetheduck
content: there's still no enforceability to the 2-subnets-per-beacon-node things, but its "slightly harder" to shirk on your duties, ie you have to modify two pieces of code instead of one

author: dmitriishmatko
content:
it's true but
- you need 64 if you have a lot validators, you cannot opt out from this
- you don't want to turn this flag on without many validators, it needs significantly more resources from client. 

Overal I'd call it top estimate

author: arnetheduck
content:
> you need 64 if you have a lot validators, you have no choice to opt out from this
why do you need 64?

author: dmitriishmatko
content:
got you
but it's 2023 year, poiinting out on this change in spec as I understand and changes in subscriptions happened after

author: dmitriishmatko
content: so actually it could be both 2000 -> 5500  (=3500) (2) growth + all remaining 64th (1000)

author: dmitriishmatko
content: but minus what you say that crawler is not very good

author: arnetheduck
content: mm fair, it's an interesting data point, specially against the need to introduce explicit "enforcement" of certain basic services that nodes provide - that said, if these nodes were to disappear, nothing would (ehh... "should") happen in the current network design

author: dmitriishmatko
content: You mean that after 64 requirement were dropped for 2, network was still healthy?

author: jimmygchen
content:
Thanks all for the discussion today! (we couldn't do a short call..)

Summary:
- Client teams are mostly working on validator custody and refactoring and making some progress.
- `peerdas-devnet-5` was launched 5 days ago and mostly running smoothly (there's a known grandine issue that needs investigation).
- Teku suggested removing peer sampling concept from the spec to reduce complexity - teams agree that it adds complexity, but there was no strong opinions on changing the spec as most teams have already implemented this. Teams to discuss offline (we should finalise this ASAP though)
- Nimbus raised a point about researching / estimating network structure with validator custody in place, in order to know more about potential sync speed on mainnet. Will add an R&D task to the readiness checklist.
- **Breakout call will be back to 1400 UTC next tuesday!**

Notes here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Ng2IrCe28kTt1BnIsjtMlKHq2MHgaja24LhFXSvqfJQ/edit?usp=sharing

author: manunlp
content: Teku suggested removing **peer** sampling concept. We still have custody sampling.

author: skylenet
content:
From `docker inspect docker.ethquokkaops.io/dh/ethpandaops/geth:PeerDAS-7f6090b`: 

```
            "Labels": {
                "buildnum": "",
                "commit": "",
                "ethpandaops.io.commitRef": "fix-downloader-race",
                "ethpandaops.io.repo": "MariusVanDerWijden/go-ethereum",
                "version": ""
            }
```

author: skylenet
content: So that would be here: https://github.com/MariusVanDerWijden/go-ethereum/commits/fix-downloader-race/

author: skylenet
content: `7f6090b` matches the most recent commit there.
